title: Apartment building with stores; Riverview Tavern, Gristede Bros: W. 181st St Northern Av (Cabrini Blvd), Manhattan
View of W. 181st St from Northern Av (Cabrini Blvd): W. 181st St Northern Av (Cabrini Blvd), Manhattan

text:
Cabrini Boulevard, west side, north of W. 181st Street, showing the Dr. Chas. V. Paterno estate being cleared. Under demolition are the greenhouses and the castle-like home of this real-estate operator. The latter, constructed in 1908 at a cost of $500,000 is of Roman and English architecture. A modern apartment house similar to Doctor Paterno's adjacent Hudson View Garden Apartments will be erected here at a reported cost of $6,000,000. Note the close proximity of the George Washington Bridge which is slightly to the S.W. of this location.

August 23, 1938.
Views 1, 2 and 3.

P. L. Sperr.

Cabrini Blvd, west side, north of W. 181st Street, showing at that location the estate and castle of Dr. Chas. V. Paterno. The photographer is viewing southward to show same and the North (Hudson) River overshadowed by the new George Washington Bridge. No.3 is a northward view to the River thru the arboraceous
loggia lining the bluff.
August 23, 1938.
Views 1,2 and 3
P. L. Sperr

Cabrini Blvd., west side, north of W 181st Street, showing the estate of Dr. Chas V. Paterno being cleared, preparatory to the construction of a 12 story detached apartment structure which will cost $6,000,000; Geo. Fred Pelham Jr. being the architect. The castle-like home of this real-estate dealer was
built of white marble in 1908 in a combined form of Roman and English architecture and is stated to have cost $500,00.
Note the George Washington Bridge and the Jersey highlands in the background.
August 23, 1938.
Views 1, 2 and 3
P.L. Sperr
